instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00164: What is 820-00164? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> light on charger, short fan spin, no chime.
threads.message:
Light on charger, short fan spin, no chime.

Found very small liquid damage on <RESISTOR>R7611</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7616</CAPACITOR> which was burned out. Replaced and still same issue.

Got light on USB.

Any idea please?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> light on charger, short fan spin, no chime.
threads.message:
USB mouse test is tricky.
If fan stops, I suppose board is not working.
Does the mouse get light if you disconnect/reconnect it?
Is alwaus better to test with OSX pendrive (with link LED).

Do you have voltage on all coils, including CPU?
Check at least for pulse on the coils...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> light on charger, short fan spin, no chime.
threads.message:
"Does the mouse get light if you disconnect/reconnect it?"
Yes

Got stable 1.80V on <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> at <CAPACITOR>C1031</CAPACITOR>

Voltage is stable on all coils:
L7310 at 1.80V
L7320 at 1.80V
L7430 at 1.21V
L7630 at 1.06V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> light on charger, short fan spin, no chime.
threads.message:
Do PRAM reset, if possible.
If <RESISTOR>R7611</RESISTOR> was open, that means overvoltage ocurred on 1V05 power rail.

"Is alwaus better to test with OSX pendrive (with link LED)."
Also check external video.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> light on charger, short fan spin, no chime.
threads.message:
Cant do PRAM reset. Nothing happens. Fews secs and is turned off. No chime. Checked on ext keyboard and same story.
Nothing on ext display.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> light on charger, short fan spin, no chime.
threads.message:
Try new BIOS.
You can also reflow PCH/CPU with good flux; just in case has some crap under...
